--- title: "Strip plot with WorldPhones" author: "Sean Ahn" date: "2024-01-22" categories: [ggplot, visualization] image: "image.png" --- Today we're going to draw a horizontal stacked bar graph. A surprisingly common use of these plots is a single bar graph lying on its side, which I call a **"strip plot"**. It's useful when you want to fill in details when drawing a pie plot, or when you want to see approximate proportions and absolute values at once. ## Initializing I usually use the following code for initialization. If you don't want to remove plots and/or variables, you can skip it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} graphics.off() rm(list = ls()) gc() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` used (Mb) gc trigger (Mb) limit (Mb) max used (Mb) Ncells 585986 31.3 1339542 71.6 NA 669405 35.8 Vcells 1078765 8.3 8388608 64.0 16384 1851683 14.2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} version ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` _ platform aarch64-apple-darwin20 arch aarch64 os darwin20 system aarch64, darwin20 status major 4 minor 3.1 year 2023 month 06 day 16 svn rev 84548 language R version.string R version 4.3.1 (2023-06-16) nickname Beagle Scouts ``` ::: ::: ## Loading Useful Library We want to use as few packages (some might call them "libraries") as possible. If possible, I'm going to use only the **tidyverse** package. [Tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org) is one of the most famous packages in R programming, and it's really powerful and useful. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€ âœ” dplyr 1.1.4 âœ” readr 2.1.4 âœ” forcats 1.0.0 âœ” stringr 1.5.1 âœ” ggplot2 3.4.4 âœ” tibble 3.2.1 âœ” lubridate 1.9.3 âœ” tidyr 1.3.0 âœ” purrr 1.0.2 â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€ âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() âœ– dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() â„¹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ::: ## Select Dataset When I write posts in my blog, I use the built-in dataset because I don't want the reader to suffer by having to find the data from somewhere else. The dataset I'll be using in this post is shown below â¬‡ï¸ â¬‡ï¸ â¬‡ï¸.
**The World's Telephones** Description The number of telephones in various regions of the world (in thousands). Usage WorldPhones Format A matrix with 7 rows and 8 columns. The columns of the matrix give the figures for a given region, and the rows the figures for a year. The regions are: North America, Europe, Asia, South America, Oceania, Africa, Central America. The years are: 1951, 1956, 1957, 1958, 1959, 1960, 1961. Source AT&T (1961) The World's Telephones. References McNeil, D. R. (1977) Interactive Data Analysis. New York: Wiley. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} WorldPhones |> head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` N.Amer Europe Asia S.Amer Oceania Africa Mid.Amer 1951 45939 21574 2876 1815 1646 89 555 1956 60423 29990 4708 2568 2366 1411 733 1957 64721 32510 5230 2695 2526 1546 773 1958 68484 35218 6662 2845 2691 1663 836 1959 71799 37598 6856 3000 2868 1769 911 1960 76036 40341 8220 3145 3054 1905 1008 ``` ::: ::: `WorldPhones` dataset is typical matrix object. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} WorldPhones |> class() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "matrix" "array" ``` ::: ::: Let's change to a dataframe to create a strip plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df <- as.data.frame(WorldPhones) ``` ::: The year is in the row name, but I removed the row name and brought it to the first column for convenient data manipulation in the future. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df <- df |> mutate(year = as.numeric(rownames(df)), .before = "N.Amer") rownames(df) <- NULL df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` year N.Amer Europe Asia S.Amer Oceania Africa Mid.Amer 1 1951 45939 21574 2876 1815 1646 89 555 2 1956 60423 29990 4708 2568 2366 1411 733 3 1957 64721 32510 5230 2695 2526 1546 773 4 1958 68484 35218 6662 2845 2691 1663 836 5 1959 71799 37598 6856 3000 2868 1769 911 6 1960 76036 40341 8220 3145 3054 1905 1008 7 1961 79831 43173 9053 3338 3224 2005 1076 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} class(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "data.frame" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dim(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 7 8 ``` ::: ::: ## Visualization `WorldPhones` is a matrix, so you can easily draw a dot plot using the built-in function as shown below. Actually, it's not bad. ğŸ¤” ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} barplot(t(WorldPhones)[,7]) title(main = "World phones data in 1961") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: However, it would be more intuitive to represent the number of phones in each country on a single line with a length proportional to the number. Drawing such a stacked bar chart is not easy with the built-in `barplot()` function. There are several ways to draw a single stacked bar plot (a.k.a. strip plot), but it is more convenient to use the geom_col() function than to use the geom_bar() function. ::: {.callout-tip} In this case, a tip is to leave the x-axis blank `aes(x = "")` for the aesthetic. ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> filter(year == "1961") |> pivot_longer(-year, names_to = "region", values_to = "num_tele") |> ggplot(aes(x = "",y = num_tele, fill = region)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We're almost there. Now you can reorient the plot, reduce its width, and fill it with a colour of your choice to create a strip plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> filter(year == "1961") |> pivot_longer(-year, names_to = "region", values_to = "num_tele") |> ggplot(aes(x = "",y = reorder(num_tele, num_tele), fill = region)) + geom_col(width = 0.5) + coord_flip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: I added labels to make it easier to see the number of phones and rotated the labels to make them easier to read. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> filter(year == "1961") |> pivot_longer(-year, names_to = "region", values_to = "num_tele") |> ggplot(aes(x = "",y = reorder(num_tele, num_tele), fill = region)) + geom_col(width = 0.5) + geom_text(aes(label = num_tele), angle = -90, position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5)) + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") + coord_flip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The last step is to add a title and a few more embellishments to finish it off. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> filter(year == "1961") |> pivot_longer(-year, names_to = "region", values_to = "num_tele") |> ggplot(aes(x = "",y = reorder(num_tele, num_tele), fill = region)) + geom_col(width = 0.5) + geom_text(aes(label = paste0(region,"\n",num_tele)), angle = -90, position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5)) + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") + coord_flip() + labs(title = "The World's Telephones at 1961", subtitle = "The number of telephones in various regions of the world (in thousands).", fill = "Region") + theme_void() + theme(plot.margin = margin(80,10,50,10), legend.position = "bottom") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Good job! ğŸ‘
